title: Temporal Causal Modeling with Graphical Granger Methods
segmentation: My name is Andrew Arnold, presenting today a paper on temporal causal modeling using graphical Granger methods.
This was work done during an internship at IBM and afterwards with Jen Lu Ann.
OK, Harvey.
So today the general outline will be starting with an introduction to the problem and some motivating examples hopefully motivating an overview of what Granger causality is.

So here's a some interesting data on the top.
You have a fictitious large East Coast computer company represented by Hal.

Then for each quarter across time, you have some performance metrics, some business performance metrics like the revenue ratio between revenue spending and R&D spending, and then some composite indices like this innovation index, which is some created index of the innovativeness of the company for that quarter.
So as a as a business professional and executive, you might look at the state and say, well, what can I figure out from this data?
How can I use this to improve my?
Chinese business.
So one intuition here is, well, it's nice to be able to mine data into find correlations between various aspects or measurements of my business.
But really, at the end of the day, I want to be able to affect change in my organization.
I'd like to find some kind of causal relationship beyond just a correlative relationship.
So one intuition is that a cause?

Necessarily, in our universe precedes its effect, so using that we can find some things like this, so this is made up data, But in this example, if we see in the third quarter of the year 2000, the innovation index is at a certain value.
That's larger than its previous value and that the revenue in the next quarter is also increased.
In another example, for the capital expenditure, the ratio between the capital expenditure to revenue.
If that goes up, then the revenue goes down the next quarter.
So again, at this point we're just seeing some correlative relationships.
We don't have any proof that these are causal relationships, but it's intriguing.
